snippet: Because some states are not expanding Medicaid, two-thirds of the poor blacks and single mothers and a majority of the low-wage workers who do not have insurance will not benefit from the new health law.
abstract: Sweeping national effort to extend health coverage to millions of Americans will leave out two-thirds of poor blacks and single mothers and a majority of low-wage workers who do not have insurance, the very people the program was intended to help; because they live in states largely controlled by Republicans that have declined to participate in expansion of Medicaid, medical insurance program for the poor, they are among eight million Americans who are impoverished, uninsured and ineligible for help.

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and ROBERT GEBELOFF

lead_paragraph: Because some states are not expanding Medicaid, two-thirds of the poor blacks and single mothers and a majority of the low-wage workers who do not have insurance will not benefit from the new health law.

headline.main: Millions of Poor Are Left Uncovered by Health Law
headline.print_headline: Millions of Poor Are Left Uncovered by Health Law

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
